In traditional grammars, དང་ is not considered to be a case (རྣམ་དབྱེ་) but a particle (ཚིག་པྲད་). This particle is used mainly as a coordinating conjunction (or connective) meaning “and” (xxlink 9.3.3 on the conjunction dang). However, it also corresponds to a case, the associative, traditionally referred to as དང་སྒྲ་, literally “sound of ‘with,’” which is generally translated as “with” or “against” or “from,” or else is not translated at all. In the literary language, it may function as a temporal connective meaning “as soon as.”

In the spoken language, this case-related function is little used, and applies to a very limited number of verbs. Furthermore, it may sometimes be replaced by other cases such as the absolutive or the oblique. Here are some verbs that still take this case in oral usage:

  • མཐུན་པོ་ “To get along with”
  • འགལ་ “To break (a law)”
  • བརྗེ་ “To exchange (for)”
  • ནོར་ “To mistake (for)”
  • ཁག་ཁག་བྱེད་ “To separate (from)”
  • Also used with certain adverbial constructions: མཉམ་པོ་ “With,” etc.

The following examples illustrate the case function of དང་:

  • རྩམ་པ་དང་བརྗེ་གི་ཡོད། “I exchange it for tsampa.”
  • ཚེ་རིང་བློ་བཟང་དང་མཐུན་པོ་འདུག “Tsering gets on well with Lopzang.”
  • ངས་མོ་དང་ཁག་ཁག་བྱེད་ཀྱི་ཡིན། “I’m going to separate from her.”
